headline: London Broil I
description: The secret to making less expensive cuts of meat tender is a good marinade. This one fits the bill. Mix up soy sauce, vegetable oil, ketchup, oregano, and three cloves of garlic, and then marinate the meat overnight. Grill, and slice on the diagonal.
name: London Broil I
recipeIngredient: 1 (2 pound) flank steak or round steak

recipeInstructions.text: In a small bowl, mix together garlic, soy sauce, oil, ketchup, oregano, and black pepper. Pierce meat with a fork on both sides. Place meat and marinade in a large resealable plastic bag. Refrigerate 8 hours, or overnight.
Lightly oil the grill grate. Place steak on the grill, and discard marinade. Cook for 5 to 8 minutes per side, depending on thickness. Do not overcook, as it is better on the rare side.

review.reviewBody: I've made this several times. It's absolutely the best marinade for London broil. I have top round London broil. 4 lbs. I just got them on sale for $1.99 lb. I add extra garlic because I love garlic.
Made this with two substitutions - sugar free ketchup and tamari instead of soy sauce. Everything else was exactly as directed and it was fantastic!!! Will definitely make this again. Thanks!!!

Excellent!
I stabbed it with a fork then used 2 tbsp of balsamic vinegar over the meat as previous reviews mentioned then followed the recipe, minus the ketchup and oregano. I marinated it for only 2 hours. Baked it for 20 minutes at 350 degrees, then broiled it for 5 minutes on each side. I turned out to be very tasty and surprisingly tender and best yet, it was so easy! My family loved it, and my kids even asked me to make it again for the next day. I didn't but loved that they loved it. Will make again soon.

This was oh, so tender! Hubby said he prefers this to a sirloin steak! I have a tenderizing device that I used before I put it into the marinade for 6 hours in the fridge. Only difference in marinade was I substituted fresh garlic for garlic powder. After marinading, I brought it to room temp and then grilled it on my Webber grill ... 10 minutes direct, flipped it and then 10 minutes indirect. My London Broil was almost 3” thick. I have an instant read thermometer and I took the meat off at 127 degrees and let it continue cooking while it rested. We like our beef cuts more rare and this was PERFECT. See photo. This recipe is a definite keeper!!

the marinade in this recipe made my Superbowl great. people who say they do not like steak couldn't get enough. (apparently there are people who don't like steak, who knew?). thank you for your recipe ??
It was delicious but I also think a thicker steak and a little more salt will not hurt it

So quick and easy, full of flavor. 
Everyone loved it. I smoked mine at 400 for 40 minutes turned out amazing!
First time but not the last I ever made a london broil.
Kids were all thumbs up!
I made this recipe and it was tasty and delicious! Next time I will marinate longer since I didn't have 8 hours to cook it.

I had a 3 lb roast, I used extra garlic (as usual for me), didn’t have the full time to let it soak in the marinade, and roasted in the oven. Still turned out very good.
425 for 15 min and finished had 350 until temp was right.
Will do this again hopefully with more time for the marinade to work.
Also the juices loaded up with lots of carmelized onion made a good sauce to use with it.
Need to use lower sodium soy sauce next time

This recipe is really good. I don't use the oregano because I prefer it that way. We use this recipe whenever London broil is on sale. You can cut really thin slices with an electric carving knife. Everyone loves it!
Made it on my grill pan indoors. Turned out delicious!
I typically use this recipe for preparing venison and it comes out great every time.
It was pretty good! I cooked it on the broiler in my oven with great success.

After I read all the reviews I tweaked this a little. Used olive oil instead of regular, cut back on the soy sauce to 1/3 cup and added 3 Tbsp of worchestershire sauce, and 3 slices of fresh lemon. Only marinated for 2 hours but did pierce meat with a meat fork every time I turned it. In the words of my son, this is the best London broil you've ever made. Thanks will do it again.
Mouth-watering marinade, grilled to perfection and enjoyed it three different meals!!
Always a winning marinade
Turned out really good. Everyone loved it. Kept it in the fridge about 5 hours instead of overnight, turned out real nice.
This is a wonderful marinade. We have used it for years and everyone loves it.
Yes did not have time to marinate full time so I made shiska Bob's added onions and green peppers nD lemon juice marinated 3 hours then grilled tender and tasty
MY FAMILY LOVED IT.
Very good!!

made this last night 
it cam out amazing 
serving size for 3
I made this recipe but served it with bleu cheese and chive butter. The marinade is amazing with the addition of balsamic vinegar!!
I used low sodium soy sauce. When I mixed it up it smelled awesome, but we found it too salty.
I pounded the cut first, then let it marinade for 2 days. Very tender.

Great recipe. To add an acid to help tenderize this very lean cut of beef, I added 1 tablespoon each of: red wine vinegar, balsamic vinegar, and worcestershire sauce, also added 1/4 teaspoon dried thyme. Even the marinade smells great! Next time I'll add about 2 tablespoon of lemon juice. Marinaded in gallon ziplock bag overnight. Cooked over low-medium covered grill, and careful to not overcook. Reapplied marinade on first flip on grill. Goes great with rice or potatoes and broccoli, asparagus, or any grilled veggies. Simple, easy, savory, and delicious. Only 4 stars because as written the recipe lacks the acid which is really needed for this cut.
I did poke all over with a fork and marinated from 9 to 5. But something was lacking; next time I want to try adding lemon to tenderize and adding Worchester for more flavor.
Used 1/4 cup of Tamara instead of soy,and increased ketchup to 2 1/2 teaspoons

So, as I was making the marinade, I'm thinking to myself 'this doesn't seem like there's anything that spectacular in it'....please believe me when I say that it was spectacular! All those basic ingredients combine to make an amazing piece of beef. 4 of my 5 kids say it's a 'make again' and the ones that have moved out, have already asked for the recipe.
It was amazing. I made it tonight exactly the way it said.

Followed the recipe, added 1/4 c. red wine vinegar and the juice of 1/2 lemon. Pricked the steak with a fork NUMEROUS times on both sides. Marinated 3 hrs then grilled until medium. This was tender and delicious! Thank you!!
This was the most flavorful, moist London broil I've ever made!
Fantastic! Only way I make London broil now. THANK YOU!
i love it this this recipe was great would recommend it to anyone

This is a great recipe and I've made it several times. It's a good combination of ingredients. I back off on the soy sauce a bit because I like to wrap it in foil to make it ready for the grill and the extra soy sauce makes it too soupy for just a 2 lb pc of meat. Otherwise it's great and I always get compliments.
We did not like at all.

It was awesome! I did add 4 Tbs of red wine vinegar for tenderizing. Mixed all measured ingredients in a bag, shook it vigorously (no extra bowls to clean!) used the Top Round London Broil after I pieced it to provide saturation of the marinade.'
Excellent. I took others suggestions and added balsamic vinegar and lemon juice to the marinade... turned out perfect. Best part, it's super easy.
marinade makes for a tasty steak. I used a top round which I pounded with a meat mallet and marinaded in a ziplock overnight.
Excellent recipe. I marinated for 24-hours and used an indoor grill. Will certainly add to the rotation here at mi casa.

I followed the recipe as directed and it was fantastic! I only marinaded it for about 6 hrs, then grilled it outside on low for about 15 min. I let it rest 5 minutes and sliced it thin. We will definitely make this again as we love London Broil!
I marinated this on 1 1/2 lb flank steak for a few hours. I added two tablespoons of balsamic to the mixture. Everyone in the house really liked it a lot.
I overcooked it by about 2-3 min. And still came out great. Better to rake it off the grill early than too late. I'm making it this week again; I have to fine-tune it.

Made exactly as recipe instructs. Put in to marinate the afternoon before. It was excellent!!! Marinade gave it a wonderful flavor, whole family raved. Easy weeknight dinner w/ leftovers for sandwiches the next day.

Wow! This was fantastic. I took the advice of some others and added Worcester Sauce and cut down on the soy sauce a bit. I also added just a few drops of liquid smoke. Let it marinade for 24 hours. Grilled it 7 minutes per side. Turned out tender, juicy an delicious. Served the meat over a salad of romaine, thin sweet onion slices, tomato and sliced strawberries. Topped with a strawberry vinaigrette. My wife said she would keep me another week!!!
The soy sauce flavor was overwhelming.

I can't cook red meat very well, just ask my husband he will back me up on this. HOWEVER, I followed the directions for this recipe only substituting fresh oregano for dried because I had it growing in a pot on the deck. The london broil turned out tender and juicey ( did I mention a cut of beef that I made turned out tender?1?!). I had a few pieces left over and was thinking about how to use them as leftovers. Well the husband has other plans and afe them as he was "helping' me clean up the kitchen" . LOL. THANKS!! 5 stars from the both of us.

This was tasty. I used the recipe as stated except as reviewers suggested, I substituted half the soy sauce with Worcestershire and I added 1 T. Lemon juice to the marinade. I poked holes with a fork in both sides of the steak then marinated for 48 hours turning and madsaging periodically. I cooked my 1.5 lb London Broil steak for 8 minutes per side in the oven broiler then let it rest for 5 minutes. It was a delicious medium rare when I cut it. Very flavorful. As an other reviewer suggested, I boiled the marinade and served it as a side sauce but it was too salty and I would not do that again. The meat, all by itself, was really flavorful. Good recipe.

I would definitely make again. I followed the instructions except that I added balsamic vinegar, about 1/4 cup and I also added some homemade steak sauce. We don't eat meat with pink and it was very tender and really, really tasty! Cooked it about 8 to 9 minutes on each side on a cast iron indoor grill pan.
This was amazing! VERY tender, delicious!
nice flavor but tough

I make this recipe exactly as stated and usually broil it in my oven when not able to grill. I have made this many times and even use it as a freezer meal. Once all the ingredients and meat are placed in a ziplock bag, I pop it in the freezer.. When I am ready to use, I let it thaw overnight and cook. It tastes amazing and so easy, love it!!! One of the best recipies I have found on all recipes.
Best London Broil I've ever made!

I made no adjustments to the recipe, but I missed the part about piercing with a fork, and I ran short on time so I marinated for just 5 hours. The steak was very good, though just a little too salty, and it was tender enough, but probably would have been better if I had followed the directions and fork-tenderized. I will definitely use this recipe again, but I will either use less soy sauce or will use low-sodium soy sauce to cut down on the saltiness.

Awesome marinade for london broil. I had just a bit under 1/2 cup of soy sauce, so I used a bit of worcestershire sauce to fill in the rest. Also added 1 extra clove of garlic. Used my Foodsaver to marinate the meat to cut down on time (marinated for 2 hours in the fridge and it marinated beautifully). Grilled for 8 minutes per side over a medium heat, came out perfectly medium rare/medium. The amount of juice that the meat produced was amazing! Never had london broil that juicy before! Side note: london broil should be cut as thin as possible, against the grain, JUST SAYIN'! Thanks for the simple, but oh-so-awesome recipe, Char!

This is realllyy good. I marinated the meat overnight and the meat turned out very flavorful. The meat was surprisingly tender too, I've always had issues with meat that gets hard when cooked which gives me toothache. So this is definitely a keeper.

I was excited about this recipe because of all the great reviews and I made it exactly as written with the exception of adding two tablespoons of lemon juice, but was WAY too salty. It does have great potential, however, but you MUST cut down on the soy sauce and maybe also use low sodium soy sauce. I will try this recipe again using 1/4 cup low sodium soy sauce and 1/4 cup Worcestershire sauce and I'm sure it will be excellent. The acid (lemon juice or vinegar) is absolutely necessary to tenderize this inexpensive cut of meat and it must be sliced very thin and across the grain. As some others have said, if you run a grilling fork all the way through the meat a good number of times you don't need to marinate it for as long as 24 hours. My finished steak had great (but too salty) flavor all the way through the meat with just 5 hours of marinating in a gallon size Ziplock bag. I grilled it on med/high heat for 6 minutes a side (grill top UP - you don't want to bake it) for a perfect medium rare, but all grills vary so your times may be different.
This is an amazing recipe!!
Awesome marinade. Only had about 90 minutes to marinade it, but it made a big difference in taste and texture. Made sure to cook it rare.

Followed the recipe exactly with the exception of adding a splash of lemon juice per other reviewers' suggestions. I marinated a thick piece of London Broil 24 hours then grilled it. It was delicious!
Love it!
Have not tried grilling. Only have broiled

I prepared the marinade this morning and let the meat soak in it all day in the refrigerator. We grilled it at a medium temperature on our gas grill for about 7 minutes on both sides. It was FABULOUS! We will definitely make it again.
Great and easy marinade, my kids gobbled the steak up and said it was really good. I only marinated the steak for 4 hours and it was still delicious! Used olive oil instead of vegetable oil.
I used this marinade on a 1.6 pound top round steak. I marinated the for 24 hours, then my husband grilled the steak to medium rare. Very nice.

I am horrible at grilling and usually eat my meat well done where my husband likes his medium rare. After reading the comments on this I thought I would give it a try for our 20th Anniversary dinner. Let me say, it was perfect. I followed the recipe to a T and was thrilled that I actually like medium rare london broil. The marinade was so good and I only had an hour to let it sit. Can't wait to use this and let it sit over night. It was cooked to perfection. Thanks for the great recipe and turning my husband back onto london broil.

Thanks previous reviewers, I used 1/4 soy sauce and 1/4 Worcestershire, added extra garlic and two tablespoons of brown sugar, reduced the sauce and poured over and loved it. The flavor was incredible. 2 days in a ziplock bag did the trick. We love spicy so I added two, ok three dashes of cayenne pepper for some kick. Will be making this with flank steak soon. I do think the meat was a little chewy, not tough so I may try vinegar nx time.

Best beef marinade I've used. I put the meat in a cooking dish to marinate, then popped it on the cool side of the grill with a foil covering. Midway through, I put the meat on the hot side for a good sear on both sides, them back onto the cool side in foil until it was done. Since the marinade was now "cooked", I used it as a sauce for the meat. Combined with the dripping from the foil it was very tasty.
Made for Father's Day and this was such a hit, we ran out. All the dads, and everyone else, loved this recipe.

Culinary experts have proven that marinades are ineffective in tenderizing meats; they really only infuse flavor. What *does* tenderize meat is salting or brining. Salt denatures proteins, making them unbind and form looser bonds. That's why this marinade works well - because of the soy sauce. The salt in soy sauce acts like a brine, helping the meat retain moisture during cooking and making it more tender. So you definitely don't want to reduce the amount of soy sauce in this recipe, as it is the tenderizing agent. But you also don't need to marinate for as long as eight hours; you will achieve very satisfactory results by marinating for one hour.
Wasn't sure how to prepare the london broil I had marinating a la Montreal. Perfect!!!
This was really great. The only reason I didn't give it 5 stars is that it was very salty. I guess low sodium soy sauce would fix that.

Tried it last night on a New York strip steak. I am never sure of the quality of the steak as we have been so disappointed in prior attempts to make a "great" steak at home. That was until last night. We were amazed how tender and flavorful the meat was and will make this marinade again.
Some people making this may be slicing the meat "with the grain". You should slice "against" the grain. If you see long strands of meat when you slice it, flip it over! Slice it at an angle.

I agree with all the 4 star ratings. I have tried to make London Broil a few times before and it always turned out like shoe leather. WOW was I wrong, this recipe made a true believer out of me. I did sprinkle some meat tenderizer on the meat(just because of the bad experience I had with this cut of beef.) I marinated for 24 hrs, Grilled for 3 to 5 each side, for med. rare and it was Wonderful. I let my husband take all the credit,(after all he was the one doing the grilling).
Favorite for london broil with added lemon juice...
This was wonderful. I marinated mine for about 8 hours. It turned out very tender.
I marinated ours for almost 3 days as someone else had suggested. The meat was very tender and full of flavor.
This turned out great! Will definitely save to use again!

Marinated London Broil over night in 1 gallon ziplock bag. Cooked 10min each side with the broiler in the oven. Smoked up the house, but this was deeeeeeelicous!! Also added 3 tbsp of lemon juice to marinade and used 3 tsp of garlic powder instead of minced garlic. YUM!
I left it overnight and we loved it! I added a bit of Dijon and Worcestershire and extra garlic though.
Family loved this! I did NOT change a thing. I left in Ziploc bag for todays it was really surprisingly good for being just a few items. I am going to try a better cut of meat next.
I followed the directions exactly because I had never cooked this cut of meat before. It was awful.

This has got to be the BEST London Broil I've ever made. Absolutely delicious. I did squeeze the juice of one lemon and added it to the marinade to help tenderize the meat. Also, I let it marinate about 36 hours, then removed from the fridge to come to room temperature before placing on the grill. I've learned room temperature beef will cook up more tender because the cold meat will "shrink" when the heat hits it. I like my beef pretty well done, and hubby likes it medium. So I grilled on high about 7 minutes per side on high heat, and the ends were perfect for me with the center being nice and pink for him. It was perfect. Thanks for this one!!!

Anti-London Broil husband was really skeptical and doubtful when he saw that I was following a recipe. However, the reviews don't lie. We scored the meat all around, marinaded overnight and ate grilled steak for less than $10! Plus I have lunch for tomorrow! Score!

Very good recipe! I marinated the london broil in a plastic bag overnight and then cooked it in the slow cooker for 6 hours...I added some whole baby mushrooms, onions, carrots, yellow, red and orange peppers (I wanted to add potatoes but I didn't have any). I put it in the slow cooker because my grill is covered in snow right now =). I can't wait to try it in the summer! It gave the veggies great flavor. I think 6 hours on low was a tad bit too long, but it was still good anyway =)

This was an easy and tasty marinade. I left it overnight and in the morn threw it in the crockpot with some potato cullings and chopped onion.Added a splash of water so the potatoes wouldn't scorch,put it on low for 61/2 hours and had the yummiest,easiest supper. Hubby polished it all off!!

Not bad! My husband had been asking for london broil for years and I stumbled across this recipe so thought I'd try it. Somehow I found a huge piece of steak labeled london broil at the grocery store for only $8. I followed this recipe but instead of garlic cloves I used a teaspoon of garlic salt.
I wasn't quite sure about grilling the meat so I also followed someone else's suggestion of broiling on high for 10 mins each side. Next time I probably just won't broil it as long to get it more tender and pink inside. Otherwise this was great and cheap!!

My husband mentioned a few times how much he liked the marinade, and even my little girls who usually turn their noses up at steak ate it. I only marinated the meat for about two hours and the meat still had a very nice flavor. Definitely making this again.
Great taste, I added salt for a 30min. marinade
Very good! Had good flavor and wasn't tough or dry at all.
I thought this was just delicious! We all had second helpings, and that's next to a miracle in this family...Did have to cook it a little longer, but I think that was our grills fault. Great recipe!
I really liked this marinade and plan on using it again!
I absolutely love the recipe for the marinade, it is delicious and flavorful. I don't use the cooking method(I don't have a grill), but the marinade is definitely worth 5+ stars.
Fantastic!
Great flavor. Because of the cut of the meat, my second try was cooked in the slow cooker.... made it tender and delicious. My hubby is loving the left overs on sweet rolls.

Great steak marinade! Since the title uses "London Broil" I decided to use "London Broil" because it was on sale. That's definitely a thicker, tougher cut of meat (it's not flank steak) and needs a longer marinating time, about 48 hours. I used this marinade for 1 & 1/2 pounds of steak. I low sodium soy sauce, olive oil vs. veg., chili sauce vs. ketchup, and added a splash of white wine vinegar. I also cut the amount of pepper in half and added 1/4 tsp. of kosher salt. I put everything into a ziploc bag and let it go, turning it every so often and rubbing the marinade into the meat. After grilling I cut it against the grain and it was not only tender and juicy, but delicious!
